page.title: Poznań bid for the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{Olympic bid|2018|Summer Youth| | logo = Olympic flag.svg | logo-size = 150px | winner = <!-- City that won the bid --> | runner-up = <!-- City that came in second place (also on the shortlist) --> | fullname = [[Poznań]], [[Poland]] | committee = [[Polish Olympic Committee]] | history = none }}
'''Poznań 2018''' was a bid by the city of [[Poznań]] and the [[Polish Olympic Committee]] to host the [[2018 Summer Youth Olympics]]. Poznan withdrew their bid on October 9, 2012 for financial reasons.<ref>http://www.aroundtherings.com/articles/view.aspx?id=41308</ref>
==History==
[[Poznań]] was revealed to be one of the bidding cities for the [[2018 Summer Youth Olympics]] when the IOC announced who the applicants were on March 2, 2012.
Poznań was one of the eight cities that hosted games during the [[UEFA Euro 2012]] championship. The [[City Stadium (Poznań)|Stadion Miejski]] hosted three matches during the championship.
Poznań, in last few years, was a host city of such sport events as the [[2011 Men's Indoor Hockey World Cup]]. In 2010 the city hosted the Academic Canoeing World Cup, Academic Basketball World Cup, European Male Basketball Cup and the European Athletic Cup for vets.<ref>[http://www.poznan2011.pl/about About Poznań] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120326165240/http://www.poznan2011.pl/about |date=2012-03-26 }}</ref> In 2006 the city hosted the Academic Futsal World Cup <ref>[http://www.fisu.net/en/Futsal-2006-453.html 10th World University Futsal Championship]</ref> and was one of the host cities for the [[2006 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship]].
On October 8, 2012 the city council rejected the proposed budget for the bid. There was a lack of financial guarantees from the city organizer and the city withdrew its bid.<ref>[http://samorzady.pb.pl/2676588,85124,poznan-nie-zorganizuje-mlodziezowych-io-w-2018-roku]</ref>
[[Buenos Aires]] was ultimately elected as the host city of the 2018 Summer Youth Olympic Games on July 4, 2013.<ref>[http://www.olympic.org/news/buenos-aires-elected-as-host-city-for-2018-youth-olympic-games/202222 Buenos Aires elected as Host City for 2018 Youth Olympic Games]</ref>
==Previous bids== [[File:Poznań 1.jpg|thumb|right|240px|View of Poznań's Old Town]]
[[Poznań]] bid to host the [[2014 Summer Youth Olympics]] but lost to [[Nanjing]] by only five votes. They bid to host the [[2010 Summer Youth Olympics]] but failed to become a candidate. Those games were ultimately awarded to [[Singapore]].
===Previous bids by other Polish cities===
[[Zakopane]] [[Zakopane bid for the 2006 Winter Olympics|bid to host]] the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] but lost to [[Turin]].
==See also== *[[Poland at the Olympics]] *[[Bids for the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics]]
==References==

revision.text:
[[File:Ski jumping hill schematic.svg|thumb|Overview of a ski jumping hill]] A '''ski jumping hill''' is a [[sports venue]] used for [[ski jumping]]. They vary in size from temporary handmade snow structures to permanent competition venues. At the top is an in-run where the jumper runs down to generate sufficient speed, before reaching the jump. The skier is then airborne until landing on the landing slope. The last part of the hill is the out-run, which may be either flat or even uphill, allowing the jumper to stop. The steepest point of the hill is the [[construction point]], which is used to determine the score of a particular length. The size of a hill is measured in the [[hill size]]. Hills with a hill size exceeding HS185 are designated [[ski flying]] hills; there are five such hills in the world.
==Structure== [[File:Lysgård.JPG|thumb|upright|The twin hills of [[Lysgårdsbakken]] in [[Lillehammer]], Norway: the normal HS100 hill to the right, the large HS138 hill to the left]]
The top of the hill is the start. This allows the jury to regulate the speed of the jumpers in varying wind conditions, by shortening or lengthening the distance along the in-run. The platform has a bar across it, which the jumper sits on. By leaning forward, the jumper will naturally start to glide down the prepared tracks along the in-run. The in-run normally has an angle of 38 to 36 degrees, which then curves into a transition; the last part of the in-run, the take-off, typically has an angle between 7 and 12 degrees downhill. The landing slope has a smooth curve which closely follows the profile of the ski jump; this means that the skier is never more than about {{convert|6|m|sp=us}} above the ground. The skier will land on the landing slope, and the rules allow jumpers to land up to ten percent past the construction point. Past the landing slope is the outrun, which is either flat or even uphill, where the skier can slow down.<ref name=east>{{cite web |url=http://www.skijumpeast.com/genhills.htm |title=Facts about Ski Jumping hills |author=Eastern Ski Jumping & Nordic Combined Foundation |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317031931/http://www.skijumpeast.com/genhills.htm |archivedate=17 March 2011 |df= }}</ref> The speed of the skier is normally measured about {{convert|10|m|sp=us}} before the end of the takeoff; jumpers can reach speeds of {{convert|95|km/h|sp=us}} on large hills and {{convert|105|km/h|sp=us}} on ski flying hills.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/27-inrun-speed |title=Inrun speed |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> [[File:Centr alimpijskaj padrychtoŭki Raŭbičy.jpg|thumb|left|View of the sports complex «[[:be:Цэнтр алімпійскай падрыхтоўкі Раўбічы|Raubichi]]» from top of the ski jumping hill, [[Belarus]]]]
In 2004, the [[International Ski Federation]] replaced the calculation point as the measurement of the size of a hill with [[hill size]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hoppbakkene bort fra K-punkt til HS-punkt |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=29 June 2004 |language=Norwegian}}</ref> The hill size is the length from the takeoff in a straight line to the knoll and then along the level of the landing slope to the hill size point.<ref name=east /> The hill size point is calculated based on the technical data of a hill based on radius, angle of inclination and record distance.<ref name=hillsize>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/24-hill-size |title=Hill size |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707224407/http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/24-hill-size |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> The calculation point or K-point is slightly further up in the hill and denotes the point where the landing slope is the steepest. It is still used for the calculation of distance points, which along with style points determine the winner of an event.<ref name=distancepoints>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/13-distance-points |title=Distance points |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707224447/http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/13-distance-points |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> For hills up to large, the scoring system grants 60 points to jumps which reach the critical point.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/5-calculation-point-k-point |title=Calculation point (K-point) |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707224439/http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/5-calculation-point-k-point |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> For ski flying hills, 120 points are granted for the critical point length. Based on the hill's length, distance points are calculated, which are added for each meter beyond the critical point and subtracted for each point shorter than the critical point. A meter has more distance points in smaller hills.<ref name=distancepoints /> Hills also have a fall line; a jumper who falls or otherwise touches the ground with their body after the fall line is not penalized.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/72-fall-line |title=Fall line |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref>
The measuring of a distance in a hill was traditionally done by people who were positioned along the hill, who would signal where the skier landed. Today this is instead measured by an advanced video system, which allows measurements in 0.5-meter increments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/11-distance-measuring |title=Distance measurement |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707224542/http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/11-distance-measuring |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Classification== {|class=wikitable ! Class !! Construction point !! [[Hill size]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/24-hill-size |title=Hill size |author=Berkutschi.com |accessdate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707224407/http://berkutschi.com/en/front/encyclopedia/show/24-hill-size |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> |- | Small hill || <45 || <50 |- | Medium hill || 45–74 || 50–84 |- | Normal hill || 75–99 || 85–109 |- | Large hill || 100–169 || 110–184 |- | [[Ski flying]] hill || ≥170 || ≥185 |}
==See also== *[[List of ski jumping hills]] *[[Red Bull 400]]
==References== {{Commons category|Ski jumping hills}} {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ski Jumping Hill}} [[Category:Ski jumping]] [[Category:Sports venues by type]] [[Category:Ski jumping venues| ]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 858379217 by [[Special:Contributions/73.25.209.165|73.25.209.165]] ([[User talk:73.25.209.165|talk]]) sub-machine guns, etc are in the reference. Please use the talk page if you have a problem with the wording
revision.text:
{{Copy to Wiktionary}} [[File:Misccaparms.jpg|thumb|350px|[[AKM]]s, [[H&K G3]] and [[RPG-7]]s found by U.S. Marines in Fallujah]] '''Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW)''' is a term used in [[arms control]] protocols to refer to two main classes of man portable weapons.<ref>https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_52142.htm NATO, Small arms and light weapons (SALW) and mine action (MA)</ref>
“[[Small arms]]” are, broadly speaking, firearms designed for individual use. They include: [[handgun]]s, [[rifle]]s, [[carbine]]s, [[sub-machine guns]], [[assault rifle]]s and [[light machine gun]]s.<ref name=UNODC-ITI />
“Light weapons” are, broadly speaking, crew-served machine guns and high-explosive projectile weapons. They include: [[general-purpose machine gun]], [[medium machine gun]]s, [[heavy machine gun]]s, [[rifle grenade]]s, [[grenade launchers]], [[automatic grenade launcher]]s, [[anti-tank rifle]]s, [[recoilless rifle]]s, [[rocket-propelled grenade]]s, [[anti-tank missile|man-portable anti-tank missiles]], [[man-portable air-defense system]]s, and [[Mortar (weapon)|mortars]] of a calibre of less than 100 millimetres.<ref name=UNODC-ITI />
Small Arms and Light Weapons also include [[ammunition]], [[explosives]], [[hand grenades]], [[land mines]] and any other man portable weapons not listed above.<ref>http://archive.ipu.org/conf-e/114/114-1.htm</ref><ref>https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_52142.htm NATO, Small arms and light weapons (SALW) and mine action (MA)</ref>
==Definition by international legal conventions== According to the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]], the international framework on firearms is composed of three main instruments: the [[Firearms Protocol]], the [[Small arms trade#United Nations Conference on the Illicit Trade in Small Arms|United Nations Programme of Action to Prevent, Combat and Eradicate the Illicit Trade in Small Arms and Light Weapons in All Its Aspects]] (Programme of Action, or PoA) and the International Instrument to Enable States to Identify and Trace, in a Timely and Reliable Manner, Illicit Small Arms and Light Weapons (International Tracing Instrument, or ITI), where only the Firearms Protocol is legally binding.
The ITI, adopted by the [[United Nations General Assembly]] on 8 December 2005, defines small arms and light weapons as:<ref name=UNODC-ITI>{{cite web |url=http://www.unodc.org/documents/organized-crime/Firearms/ITI.pdf |title=International Instrument to Enable States to Identify and Trace, in a Timely and Reliable Manner, Illicit Small Arms and Light Weapon |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=25 February 2013 |website=unodc.org |publisher=United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
{{quote|any man-portable lethal weapon that expels or launches, is designed to expel or launch, or may be readily converted to expel or launch a shot, bullet or projectile by the action of an explosive, excluding antique small arms and light weapons or their replicas. Antique small arms and light weapons and their replicas will be defined in accordance with domestic law. In no case will antique small arms and light weapons include those manufactured after 1899:
(a) “Small arms” are, broadly speaking, weapons designed for individual use. They include, inter alia, revolvers and self-loading pistols, rifles and carbines, sub-machine guns, assault rifles and light machine guns;
(b) “Light weapons” are, broadly speaking, weapons designed for use by two or three persons serving as a crew, although some may be carried and used by a single person. They include, inter alia, general purpose or universal machine guns, medium machine guns, heavy machine guns, rifle grenades, under-barrel grenade launchers and mounted grenade launchers, portable anti-aircraft guns, portable anti-tank guns, recoilless rifles, man portable launchers of anti-tank missile and rocket systems, man portable launchers of anti-aircraft missile systems, and mortars of a calibre of less than 100 millimetres.<ref name=UNODC-ITI />}}
Such [[arms control]] policies and treaties are focused on international [[arms trafficking]] (importation and export), and in the standardization of laws, protocols and sharing of law enforcement information and best practices across nations to prevent illicit arms sales. They also focus on terrorism, arms proliferation as a humanitarian concern, disarmament in the face of extreme violence, and cases of ameliorating anarchy, civil war and international conflict. SALW provisions are generally not oriented towards imposing or enforcing domestic national or local legislation of legitimate gun ownership or sale.<ref name=UNODA-SALW>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/disarmament/convarms/SALW/ |title=UNODA: Small Arms and Light Weapons |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2013 |website=un.org |publisher=United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
==UN SALW control efforts== [[File:Flag of the United Nations.svg|right|150px]]
[[Small arms]] and light weapons are used in conflicts around the world, causing injury and death.<ref name=SALW-Control>{{cite web|url=http://www.unddr.org/iddrs/04/11.php |title=4.11 SALW Control, Security & Development |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430043852/http://www.unddr.org/iddrs/04/11.php |archivedate=30 April 2009 |df= }}</ref> Small arms control was first broached by UN Resolution A/RES/46/36 (December 1991), which was expanded upon by A/RES/50/70 (January 1996).<ref name=UNRes5070>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/depts/ddar/Register/Resolutions/5070.htm |title= General and complete disarmament: Transparency in armaments |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=15 January 1996 |website=un.org |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=19 May 2011}}</ref> This latter resolution mandated a panel of experts to research the type of small arms and light weapons being used in the world's conflicts and to study which weapons might apply to fall under an arms control regime. The recommendations of expert reports returned to the General Assembly, A/52/298 (1997) and A/54/258 (1999)<ref>{{cite web|title=Report of the Group of Governmental Experts on Small Arms, 1999|url=http://www.un-casa.org/CASAUpload/ELibrary/1999%20GGE.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008071925/http://www.un-casa.org/CASAUpload/ELibrary/1999%20GGE.pdf|archivedate=8 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> led to a July 2001 [[Small arms trade#United Nations Conference on the Illicit Trade in Small Arms|United Nations Conference on the Illicit Trade in Small Arms]], with a follow-up in July 2006.
On 26 September 2013 the UN Security Council passed Resolution 2117, which urged nations to remain committed to small arms embargoes and SALW control protocols.<ref name=UNRes2117>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/RES/2117%282013%29 |title=Resolution 2117 (2013) |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=26 September 2013 |website=un.org |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
Work on SALW via the United Nations is coordinated by the [[United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs|Office for Disarmament Affairs]] (UNODA), though the UN Coordinating Action on Small Arms (CASA) mechanism, which comprises 21 UN departments and agencies working on different aspects of small arms and light weapons control.<ref>{{cite web|title=CASA Participants|url=http://www.un-casa.org/SecCASAMEMBER/MembersOfCasa.aspx|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923185907/http://www.un-casa.org/SecCASAMEMBER/MembersOfCasa.aspx|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-09-23}}</ref> The [[United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research]] (UNIDIR), carries out research in arms control affairs and has published many articles and books related to small arms and light weapons.<ref>{{cite web|title=UNIDIR selected publications and activities related to small arms|url=http://www.unidir.ch/bdd/focus-search.php?onglet=5|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610112243/http://www.unidir.ch/bdd/focus-search.php?onglet=5|archivedate=10 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 2 April 2013, the UN General Assembly voted overwhelmingly to adopt the [[Arms Trade Treaty]] (ATT) to govern the legal international trade in many types of conventional weapons, from warships and aircraft to small arms and light weapons.<ref name=UN-ATT>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/disarmament/ATT/ |title=The Arms Trade Treaty |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2013 |website=un.org |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref> A basic obligation of the treaty is that all States Parties should establish or maintain controls in the area. In this way, the treaty also helps the international community to address unregulated or illegal trade in conventional weapons. The treaty opened for signature on 3 June 2013. To date, two-thirds of UN member states have signed the treaty (130 states), and 72 have ratified it. The treaty entered into force on December 24, 2014.<ref>https://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XXVI-8&chapter=26&lang=en</ref>
==Other SALW regimes and control organizations==
Many other related governmental bodies and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) also work on SALW control, major examples being [[IANSA (NGO)|IANSA]], [[Saferworld]] and the [[Control Arms Campaign]]. Regional and sub-regional organizations working on SALW control include the [[African Union]], [[ECCAS]], the [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS), [[Southern African Development Community]], [[Andean Community]], [[CARICOM]], [[MERCOSUR]], [[Organization of American States]] (OAS), [[European Union]], the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]], [[ASEAN]], the [[League of Arab States]], and the [[Pacific Islands Forum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.poa-iss.org/RegionalOrganizations/RegionalOrganizations.aspx |title=PoA-ISS: Regional Organizations |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2014 |website=poa-iss.org |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
== Global distribution of small arms == {{for|a more detailed list of common firearms|List of most-produced firearms}}
In 2018, [[Small Arms Survey]] reported that there are over one billion small arms distributed globally, of which 857 million (about 85 percent) are in [[civilian]] hands.<ref>http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/de/about-us/highlights/2018/highlight-bp-firearms-holdings.html Small Arms Survey reveals: More than one billion firearms in the world</ref><ref>http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/fileadmin/docs/T-Briefing-Papers/SAS-BP-Civilian-Firearms-Numbers.pdf Estimating Global CivilianHELD Firearms Numbers. Aaron Karp. June 2018</ref> U.S. civilians alone account for 393 million (about 46 percent) of the worldwide total of civilian held firearms.<ref>http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/fileadmin/docs/T-Briefing-Papers/SAS-BP-Civilian-Firearms-Numbers.pdf Estimating Global CivilianHELD Firearms Numbers. Aaron Karp. June 2018</ref> This amounts to "120.5 firearms for every 100 residents."<ref>http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/fileadmin/docs/T-Briefing-Papers/SAS-BP-Civilian-Firearms-Numbers.pdf Estimating Global CivilianHELD Firearms Numbers. Aaron Karp. June 2018</ref> The worlds [[armed forces]] control about 133 million (about 13 percent) of the global total of small arms, of which over 43 percent belonging to two countries the Russian Federation (30.3 million) and China (27.5 million).<ref>http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/de/about-us/highlights/2018/highlight-bp-firearms-holdings.html Small Arms Survey reveals: More than one billion firearms in the world</ref> [[Law enforcement agency|Law enforcement agencies]] control about 23 million (about 2 percent) of the global total of small arms.<ref>http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/de/about-us/highlights/2018/highlight-bp-firearms-holdings.html Small Arms Survey reveals: More than one billion firearms in the world</ref>
==See also== * [[Small arms]] * [[Small Arms Survey]] * [[Small arms trade]] * [[Arms Trade Treaty]] * [[Gun control]] * [[Gun politics]] * [[List of most-produced firearms]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://fas.org/asmp/ Arms Sales Monitoring Project] at the Federation of American Scientists (FAS) * [https://www.un.org/disarmament/convarms/SALW/ Small Arms and Light Weapons] at United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs (UNODA) * [http://www.controlarms.org/ Control Arms campaign] * [http://www.poa-iss.org/CASA/CASA.aspx Coordinating Action on Small Arms] United Nations Programme of Action, Implementation Support System * [http://www.iansa.org International Action Network on Small Arms (IANSA)] * [http://www.maginternational.org Mines Advisory Group (MAG)] * [http://www.pogo.org/search/?cx=011767708521316336744%3Aeby5o1uug_4&cof=FORID%3A10&ie=UTF-8&q=small+arms&sa=Go Project On Government Oversight (POGO)] "small arms" search results * [http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/ Small Arms Survey] * [http://www.seesac.org/publication.php?l1=65 SALW Knowledge Base] at South Eastern and Eastern Europe Clearinghouse for the Control of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SEESAC) * [http://www.un-casa.org/ United Nations Coordinating Action on Small Arms] * [http://www.unidir.org/ United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research] * [http://www.fco.gov.uk/servlet/Front?pagename=OpenMarket/Xcelerate/ShowPage&c=Page&cid=1007029393987 UK Foreign & Commonwealth Office: Small Arms and Light Weapons] * [http://www.wassenaar.org/ The Wassenaar Arrangement] on Export Controls for Conventional Arms and Dual-Use Goods and Technologies
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2017}}
The '''Olympic Village of Tegucigalpa''' is a [[sports complex]] situated in the northeastern part<ref>[http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/google_map_Tegucigalpa.htm Google Maps]</ref> of [[Tegucigalpa]], the capital of [[Honduras]]. The [[Government of Honduras]] designed the complex to serve as the city's main sports center, and also to provide accommodation for athletes participating in international events. It is located to the north of the [[Universidad Nacional Autónoma de Honduras|Autonomous National University of Honduras]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tegucigalpa|url=http://www.davishunter.com/home/place/Tegucigalpa|website=DavisHunter.com|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> Entry is free of charge and there are facilities for many types of sport.<ref name=touristeye>{{Cite web |url= http://www.touristeye.com/Villa-Olimpica-Tegucigalpa-p-18340 |title= Villa Olimpica |website= www.touristeye.com |access-date= 2016-10-16}}</ref> It is owned by the state of [[Honduras]] and managed by the National Commission for Sporting Installations (CONAPID), within a monthly budget of 10 million ''[[Honduran lempira|lempiras]]''.
== History == The Tegucigalpa Olympic Village was built in 1989, during the presidency of [[José Azcona del Hoyo]]. It was designed by various architects and engineers from [[Tegucigalpa]], aiming to modernize the area and to be capable of accommodating the [[Central American and Caribbean Games]].
== Facilities == The Olympic village includes a variety of facilities with sports equipment, including [[weight training|weights]], [[gymnasiums]], [[Olympic-size swimming pool|an Olympic-size swimming pool]], several [[Association football|football]] pitches, [[basketball]], [[volleyball]], and [[tennis]] courts.
===Structures=== The buildings of the facility include: * Swimming pools. * Gymnasium 1: Area designated to the disciplines of [[Olympic gymnastics]], boxing, table tennis, [[Muay Thai]], [[Kickboxing]] and [[Lima Lama]]. * Gymnasium 2: [[Volleyball]], [[fencing]] and [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]]. * Gymnasium 3: [[Basketball]] and [[martial arts]] (including [[Muay Thai]]) * Chochi Sosa Baseball Stadium ([[Estadio Chochi Sosa]]), 1,500 seats. * [[Olympic Stadium|Olympic stadium]]: [[Association football|football]] and [[Sport of athletics|athletics]], 3,000 seats.
=== Sports === {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Aikido]] * [[Gymnastics]] * [[Basketball]] * [[Handball]] * [[Boxing]] * [[Baseball]] * [[Table tennis]] * [[Fencing]] * [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]] * [[Association football|Football]] * [[Tennis]] * [[Karate]] * [[Kung fu (term)|Kung fu]] * [[Taekwondo]] * [[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] * [[Sport of athletics|Athletics]] * [[Volleyball]] * [[Wrestling]] * [[Muay Thai|Muay thai]] * [[Judo]] * [[Mixed martial arts]] * [[Lima Lama]] * [[Kickboxing]] {{div col end}}
== Access == The Olympic Village is open to the public from 4:00 am until 8:00 pm daily. No fee is charged to use the facilities,<ref name="Travel2016">{{cite book|author=Avalon Travel|title=Moon Central America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cew_DgAAQBAJ&pg=PT2923|date=2 February 2016|publisher=Avalon Publishing|isbn=978-1-63121-416-5|pages=2923–}}</ref> as the complex is regarded as the property of all Hondurans. It typically receives at least 10,000 visits a day, attracting many walkers and runners as a relatively safe place within the city.<ref name="Travel2016" />
== Maintenance == The maintenance of the Olympic Village is the responsibility of CONAPID, using funding of less than 10 million lempiras per month. This funding is derived mainly from rental income and advertising at the [[Estadio Tiburcio Carías Andino|Tiburcio Carías Andino Stadium]].
The Olympic Village does not collect fees from the public for provision of the installations, although sports organisations do levy a minimal charge to raise funds for participation in international competitions. It has been noted{{by whom|date=October 2017}} that with the constant increase of the price of all resources, adequate maintenance of the complex would require the government to increase the budgetary allocation by at least 30 million ''lempiras''.
== Renovation == CONAPID secured a grant of one million dollars, equivalent to some 20 million ''lempiras'', from the [[Central American Integration System|Central American Bank for Economic Integration (BCIE)]] to renovate the Olympic Village. At present it receives adequate maintenance, with 3.5 million ''lempiras'' allocated to its maintenance in 2008.
Germán Duarte, the current supervisor of projects, is engaged with the repair of pitches and the repainting of floors in the three gymnasiums of the sports complex. A new roof has been provided at the Olympic swimming pool, stairways and perimeter fences have been repainted, and several planting areas have been improved.
Further improvements undertaken by CONAPID during 2015, at a cost of 14 million ''lempiras'', included fitting over 300 [[LED light]]s, resurfacing all the main roadways, and a new [[tartan track]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Modernizan la Villa Olímpica de Tegucigalpa|url=http://tiempo.hn/modernizan-la-villa-olimpica-de-tegucigalpa/|work=Diario Tiempo Digital|date=21 August 2015|language=es-ES}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Sport in Honduras]] * [[Soccer in Honduras]] * [[Basketball in the United States]] * [[Ingenieros Coliseum]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.conapid.gob.hn/ CONAPID] (Comision Nacional pro Instalaciones Deportivas y Mejoramiento del Deporte) * [http://clubabejitas.com/ Club Artistic Gymnastics Tegucigalpa Abejitas]
{{coord|14.0908|N|87.1638|W|source:wikidata|display=title}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} '''The Lawn Ground''' was located in [[Nailsworth]], [[Gloucestershire]], [[England]], and was, from 1890 to 2006, home to the English football club, [[Forest Green Rovers F.C.|Forest Green Rovers]] who currently play in [[EFL League Two|League 2]]. The Lawn Ground also hosted local cup finals as well as being home to Forest Green's Ladies and youth sides.
The ground was located at the top of a steep hill in the hamlet of Forest Green and had a total capacity of 5,141 people. Forest Green matches drew approximately 1,000 spectators on average at the Lawn Ground. The ground's record attendance is 3,002 for a match between Forest Green and [[St Albans City F.C.|St Albans City]], in a [[FA Trophy]] semi-final on 18 April 1999.
Until the 1950s, the Lawn was little more than an open field, but the Rovers' success required upgrades to the stadium. At this point, terraces were constructed for fans and a "famously partial leveling of the pitch" occurred.
In 1996, the Trevor Horsley Stand, named after the chairman of the club, Trevor Horsley, was constructed for over £200,000. This stand seated 300 and included three hospitality boxes, underground changing rooms, a board room, function room, bar, a health suite and offices. It also featured a quirky [[watermill]] behind the stand. Aside from the Trevor Horsley Stand, the rest of the ground, about 80 percent, was terraced.
The biggest terrace stand was the covered Barnfield Terrace. The terrace was built during 2001 and 2002 to increase the ground's capacity, and Forest Green fans paid to have their names engraved onto bricks inside that stand. The Barnfield Terrace was sponsored by Rockwool. When the club left the ground at the end of the [[2005-06 in English football|2005-2006 season]], the stand was transferred brick by brick to their new ground.
Other sections of the Lawn Ground included the Nympsfield Road Terrace which was located behind a goal at the northern end of the ground.
The Lawn Ground was demolished and turned into housing after the club moved into the new, modern [[The New Lawn|The New Lawn Stadium]], which now hosts all their matches. Forest Green began playing at the new stadium which is only a few hundred yards from the old Lawn, from the start of the [[2006-07 in English football|2006-2007 season]].<ref name="new lawn">{{cite web | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Forest Green Rovers | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = Football Ground Guide | date = 13 January 2007 | url = http://www.conferencegrounds.co.uk/forest_green_rovers.htm | accessdate =11 October 2007 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox Stadium |stadium_name = Tripoli International Stadium |image = [[Image:Tehaa-Fans-SuperCup-BenTaher.jpg|250px|Al Ittihad Fans at the stadium during the Libyan Super Cup]] |location = [[Tripoli]], [[Libya]] |opened = 1970 |nickname = Africa's Graveyard |renovated = |expanded = |closed = |demolished = |owner = |operator = |surface = Grass |construction_cost = |architect = |structural engineer = |services engineer = |general_contractor = |project_manager = |main_contractors = |former_names = June 11 Stadium |tenants = [[Libya national football team]]
[[Al-Ahli SC (Tripoli)|Alahly Tripoli S.C]]
[[Al-Ittihad Club (Tripoli)|Alittihad S.C]]
[[Al-Madina SC|Almadina S.C]] |capacity = 88,000 |record attendance = 100,000 |dimensions = {{convert|72|m|yd|0}} by {{convert|107|m|yd|0}}[http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?showstadiums=1&searchcountry=LY&stadium=419 Information at goalzz.com] }} The '''Tripoli International Stadium''' ({{lang-ar|ملعب طرابلس}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Tripoli]], [[Libya]]. It can hold 88,000 spectators. It is the main venue used by the [[Libya national football team|Libyan national football team]] in its FIFA World Cup and African Nations Cup qualifying matches as well as friendlies and other international games. [[File:11 June Stadium BenTaher.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Tripoli Stadium]] The stadium hosted many games of the [[1982 African Cup of Nations]] held in Libya along with the [[28 March Stadium]] in [[Benghazi]]; it was the venue for the final between Ghana and Libya. It hosted the 2002 [[Italian Supercup]] between [[Juventus]] and [[Parma F.C.|Parma]], which Juventus won, 2–1. Its old name (June 11 Stadium) is a reference to the date of the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Libya, June 11, 1970. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|32|51|35.53|N|13|8|9.16|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = [[African Cup of Nations]]
Final Venue | years = [[1982 African Cup of Nations|1982]] | before = [[Lagos National Stadium|National Stadium]]
[[Lagos]] | after = [[Stade Félix Houphouët-Boigny]]
[[Abidjan]] }} {{s-end}} {{Libyan Premier League Venues}} {{Tripoli}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1982]] [[Category:Football venues in Libya]] [[Category:Sports venues in Libya]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Libya]] [[Category:National stadiums|Libya]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tripoli]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Libya]] [[Category:1982 establishments in Libya]] {{Libya-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox venue | image = [[File:Twerton Park.jpg|250px]] | caption = 2009 Conference South Play Off Final between [[Bath City]] and [[Woking FC]] | stadium_name = Twerton Park | nickname = Twerton Park | fullname = Twerton Park | location = Dominion Road, Twerton, Bath, BA2 1DB | built = 1909 | opened = 26 June 1909 | seating_capacity = 8,840 (1,006 seated) | record_attendance = 18,020 | surface = Grass | tenants = [[Bath City F.C.|Bath City]] ''(1932–)
'' [[Bristol Rovers]] ''(1986–1996)''
[[Team Bath F.C.|Team Bath]] ''(1999–2009)'' | dimensions = 101 x 69 m[http://www.bathcityfc.com/club_info.htm Bath City FC Information] | website = {{URL | http://www.bathcityfc.com}} }} '''Twerton Park''' is a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in the [[Twerton]] suburb of [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], [[England]]. It is currently used for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[Bath City F.C.|Bath City]]. From 1986 to 1996 [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] played there following their departure from [[Eastville Stadium|Eastville]]. The stadium has a capacity of 8,840 people, with 1,066 seats. The ground was opened on 26 June 1909 as '''Innox Park''' on land that had been donated by Thomas Carr. The opening ceremony involved a parade of scholars, the singing of [[hymn]]s and a speech by the chairman of the [[Parish councils in England|parish council]].Byrne, Stephen & Jay, Mike (2003): Bristol Rovers Football Club, The Definitive History 1883-2003. {{ISBN|0-7524-2717-2}} Twerton Park became Bath City's ground in 1932. A record attendance of 18,020 was recorded in 1960 versus [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. The ground has also hosted [[Team Bath F.C.|Team Bath]], who were a full-time professional team playing in the [[Conference South]] until their resignation at the end of the 2008–09 season. At the end of the 2011–12 season the club offered the naming rights to Twerton Park for just £50. The offer drew 167 entries from as far afield as the US, Australia, Norway and Singapore which raised £3,850 for the club. Businesses made up 58 of the entries with only a handful of the remaining personalised entries being deemed unsuitable. The winning entry drawn at random was The Mayday Trust, a charitable organisation that helps to rehome vulnerable people.{{cite web|title=Bath City's football ground to become Mayday Trust Park|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-17656281|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 December 2017}} Talks have been held in the past between [[Bath Rugby]] and Bath City about sharing a ground, as the former team wish to move away from their home ground [[Recreation Ground (Bath)|Recreation Ground]], although nothing has amounted from this. Following the resignation of Chairman Manda Rigby, she claimed that the club needed to move away from Twerton Park to "sustain their finances".{{cite news |url=http://www.bathchronicle.co.uk/question-mark-future-bath-city-fc-s-twerton/story-20358188-detail/story.html |title=Question mark over the future of Bath City FC's Twerton ground |newspaper=Bath Chronicle |date=23 December 2013 |accessdate=14 July 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bathcityfc.com/ Bath City FC Website] *[http://www.twerton.com/ Twerton Community Site] {{Conference National Venues}} {{Bristol Rovers F.C.}} {{coord|51.3787|-2.3951|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1909]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues in Bath, Somerset]] [[Category:Bath City F.C.]] [[Category:Bristol Rovers F.C.]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1909 establishments in England]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] {{England-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''White Nights''' (also known as ''St. Petersburg White Nights'', {{lang-ru|Белые ночи}}) is an open international [[badminton]] tournament in [[Russia]]. This tournament has been an [[BWF International Challenge|International Challenge]] level and part of [[Badminton Europe]] circuit.{{cite web|title=INTERNATIONAL CHALLENGE TOURNAMENT "WHITE NIGHTS 2016"|url=http://www.russkikh.com/whitenights-2016/participation/|website=russkikh.com|accessdate=19 December 2016}} ==Previous winners== {| class=wikitable style="font-size:90%;" !Year !Men's singles !Women's singles !Men's doubles !Women's doubles !Mixed doubles |- | 1983
